children.name: very easy to notice or understand
obvious b1
children.definition: obvious something that is obvious is very easy to notice or understand:rõ ràng
examples: ▪ there is an obvious connection between the two murders.
▪ ‘why is she leaving?’ ‘well, it’s obvious, isn’t it?’
it is obvious that
▪ it’s obvious that something is wrong.
▪ it was obvious from the start that my parents disliked nancy.
it is obvious to sb
▪ it should be obvious to everyone that we need to make some changes.
for obvious reasonswhen the reasons are so obvious that you do not need to say what they are
▪ for obvious reasons, we’ve had to cancel tonight’s performance.
obviously[adverb] b1 use this to emphasize that it is easy to see that sth is true:rõ ràng
▪ we’re obviously going to need more help.
▪ obviously, this guy’s a complete fraud.

children.name: clear a2
children.definition: clear/klɪəʳ/  if it is clear that something is true, it is easy to notice that it is true and you feel sure about it and have no doubts: it is clear thatrõ ràng
examples: ▪ it was clear that lesley was very upset by what had happened.
it is clear to somebody
▪ it was clear to me that my father was dying.
it becomes clear
▪ it soon became clear that there were not enough police officers to deal with the situation.
▪ it became clear after talking to him that andrew wasn’t going to cooperate.
clear evidence/example/sign etc
▪ there is clear evidence that certain diets reduce your chances of getting cancer.
▪ clear signs of an economic recovery
clearly[adverb] a2 use this to emphasize that it is easy to see that sth is true:rõ ràng
▪ clearly, the situation is more complicated than we first thought.
▪ the children were clearly upset.
▪ the language of the article clearly reveals the author’s bias.

children.name: can tell u
children.definition: can tell/kən ˈtel/  to know that something must be true because you can see signs that show this:có thể nói
examples: can tell (that)
có thể nói (là)
▪ i can tell that mark isn’t happy here.
▪ even though it was dark, she could tell it was him.
can tell if
có thể nói rằng
▪ i can’t tell if this is dirty or not. can you?
can tell by
có thể nói trước
▪ i could tell by the way she walked that her knee was still bothering her.

children.name: it is easy to see u
children.definition: it is easy to see/ɪt ɪz ˌiːzi tə ˈsiː/ if it is easy to see that something is true, it is very easy for anyone to notice or understand that fact: dễ dàng thấy
examples: it is easy to see (that)
▪ it’s easy to see that he isn’t well.
▪ it was easy to see that minna was embarrassed by her father’s behaviour.
it is easy to see how/why/what
▪ it’s easy to see why this place is so popular.

children.name: noticeable c1
children.definition: noticeable a noticeable difference, change, improvement etc is easy to notice:có thể thấy rõ
examples: noticeable change
▪ the most noticeable change was in my younger brother, who had grown quite a bit and was now a third-grader.
noticeable improvement
▪ there has been a noticeable improvement in jeremy’s behaviour lately.
barely/hardly/scarcely noticeablealmost not noticeable
▪ stop worrying about your pimples; they’re barely noticeable.
it is noticeable that
▪ it was quite noticeable that everyone had been invited except for gail.
noticeably[adverb]
▪ the performance was noticeably better during the second half of the concert.

children.name: perceptible x
children.definition: perceptible formal a perceptible difference, change, improvement etc can be noticed even though it is small:có thể nhận thức thấy
examples: ▪ the influence of sartre is perceptible in hogan’s novel.
perceptible change
▪ according to reynolds, there has been a slight but perceptible change in public attitude lately.
barely/scarcely/hardly perceptiblealmost not perceptible
▪ his lips curved in a barely perceptible smile.
▪ when he asked if she wanted something to eat, she gave a barely perceptible nod.
perceptibly[adv]
▪ outdoors, it was perceptibly colder.

children.name: definite b2
children.definition: definite/distinctc1  a distinct or definite possibility, feeling, quality etc is noticeable and cannot be ignored:dễ thấy, rõ ràng
examples: distinct/definite possibility
▪ a civil war is a distinct possibility.
▪ food shortages are so severe that mass starvation is a definite possibility.
distinct advantage
▪ trigg’s height should give him a distinct advantage in his match against robinson.
distinct impression
▪ i had the distinct impression that rachel was displeased.
distinctly/definitelyb1[adverb]
▪ i distinctly heard the noise again, this time coming from the cellar.

children.name: apparent b2
children.definition: apparent/evidentb2  obvious - used formally or in literature:rõ rành rành, rõ ràng
examples: ▪ even at the age of eight his musical talent was apparent.
for no apparent reasonwithout a clear reason
▪ suddenly, and for no apparent reason, he turned his back and walked away.
it is evident (from something) that
▪ from the look on jill’s face, it was evident that the news came as a complete shock.
it became apparent/evident that
▪ it became evident that lena wasn’t going to be able to handle the project on her own.
▪ after a few months, it became apparent that vicky did not have a genuine interest in her job.

children.name: conspicuous x
children.definition: conspicuous sth or someone that is conspicuous is very easy to notice, because they are different from everything or everyone else around them:lồ lộ, đập ngay vào mắt
examples: ▪ cuzco’s few tourists are conspicuous as they explore the old cobbled streets.
▪ downtown business owners say they want the city’s homeless shelter moved to a less conspicuous location.
conspicuously[adverb]rõ ràng, dễ thấy
▪ airport officials became suspicious when the man tried to check what they describe as a conspicuously heavy bag.

children.name: extremely obvious and impossiblenot to notice
unmistakable x
children.definition: unmistakable/ˌʌnmɪˈsteɪkəbəl, ˌʌnməˈsteɪkəbəl/  không thể nhầm lẫn
examples: unmistakable sight/sound/smell etc
▪ the secretary of state said the measures are designed to send the regime a clear and unmistakable signal.
▪ the unmistakable sounds of mariachi music
unmistakably[adverb]
▪ the woman’s accent was unmistakably french.

children.name: quite obvious b1
children.definition: quite obvious/ perfectlyb2/ blindingly informal so obvious that it is impossible not to notice:thật quá/ hoàn toàn rõ ràng
examples: ▪ the reason she stopped smoking is perfectly obvious: she’s pregnant.
▪ a blindingly obvious mistake

children.name: speaks for itself c2
children.definition: speaks for itself/ˌspiːks fər ɪtˈself/  if you say that a fact speaks for itself, you mean it shows that something is so obviously good or obviously bad that you do not need to tell people how good or bad it is:chính nó đã nói rõ rồi
examples: ▪ the quality of our products speaks for itself.
▪ the fact that so many parents refuse to send their children to the school speaks for itself.

children.name: self-evident x
children.definition: self-evident formal facts, ideas etc that are self-evident are obvious and true, although some people may not accept them or know about them: hiển nhiên
examples: ▪ the facts in this case are self-evident and cannot be denied.
▪ self-evident truths
it is self-evident that
▪ it is self-evident to most people that the government is under no obligation to finance the arts.

children.name: stands out a mile x
children.definition: it sticks/stands out a mile/ɪt ˌstɪks, ˌstændz aʊt ə ˈmaɪl/ british informal you say it sticks or stands out a mile when you think that someone’s character, feelings, or background are obvious: nó rõ mồn một
examples: ▪ i’m absolutely sure he’s a retired army officer. it sticks out a mile.
▪ you can see he’s desperately jealous. it stands out a mile.

children.name: stands out like a sore thumb x
children.definition: it sticks/stands out like a sore thumb/ɪt ˌstɪks, ˌstændz aʊt laɪk ə ˌsɔːʳ ˈθʌm/ you say it sticks or stands out like a sore thumb when something looks very different from everything around it:rất chướng mắt
examples: ▪ i’m not going to the party dressed like this - i’d stick out like a sore thumb.

children.name: you only have to x
children.definition: you just/only have to .../juː ˈdʒʌst, ˈəʊnli hæv tuː/ you say that you only have to look at something, read something etc when you think something is so obvious that anybody will notice it:bạn chỉ cần
examples: ▪ you only have to look at turner’s later oil paintings to see what a genius he was.
▪ you just have to look at family photos from that time to see that there was a lot of sadness and bitterness over my parents’ divorce.

children.name: be written all over sb’s face x
children.definition: be written all over somebody’s face/biː ˌrɪtn ɔːl əʊvəʳ somebodyˈs ˈfeɪs/  if you say that a fact or feeling is written all over someone’s face you mean that you can see, just by looking at the expression on their face, that it is true:viết hết lên mặt ai đó
examples: ▪ you’re in love with him. it’s written all over your face.
▪ when joey opened the package and saw that it wasn’t a fire engine, the disappointment was written all over his face.

children.name: you can’t miss it x
children.definition: you can’t miss it/juː ˌkɑːnt ˈmɪs ɪtǁ-ˌkænt-/ you say you can’t miss it when you are giving someone directions to a place that is very easy to find or notice:bạn không thể không thấy nó
examples: ▪ their house is on the left. it has a pink door. you can’t miss it.

children.name: be staring sb in the face x
children.definition: be staring somebody in the face/biː ˌsteərɪŋ somebody ɪn ðə ˈfeɪs/  if something such as a solution to a problem is staring you in the face, it is very obvious - use this especially when someone does not notice or realize something even though it is very obvious:lồ lộ trên mặt ai đó
examples: ▪ the solution was staring me in the face.
▪ the answer had been staring him in the face for months.

children.name: when sth wrong, bad, or dishonest is very obvious
blatant x
children.definition: blatant/ˈbleɪtənt/  use this about something that someone does which is clearly bad, but which they do not seem to be ashamed of: rành rành, hiển nhiên
examples: ▪ a blatant lie
▪ the company’s refusal to hire him was a blatant act of discrimination.
▪ a blatant disregard for public safety
blatantly[adverb]
▪ blatantly racist comments

children.name: flagrant x
children.definition: flagrant/ˈfleɪgrənt/  done in a very obvious way and showing no respect for laws, rules, or the truth etc:rành rành, hiển nhiên, rõ ràng
examples: ▪ the regime has often been criticized for its flagrant abuses of human rights.
▪ poison gas was used, in flagrant disregard of the geneva convention.
flagrantly[adverb]rành rành, hiển nhiên, rõ ràng
▪ for over six years, the mayor and his cronies have flagrantly misused public funds.

children.name: glaring x
children.definition: glaring/ˈgleərɪŋ/  use this about mistakes or problems that are obviously bad or wrong: rành rành, hiển nhiên, rõ ràng
examples: ▪ it was a glaring error, which cost the company over $2 million in lost business.
▪ ‘it was a glaring example of bad judgment,’ said one official who asked not to be named.

children.name: patently x
children.definition: patently formal
examples: patently false/absurd/ridiculous/impossible etcobviously false, absurd etc, in a way that no reasonable person could disagree with: rõ rành rành, hiển nhiên, rõ ràng
▪ jenkins’ explanation of the situation is patently absurd.
▪ the statement is patently false and an embarrassing public demonstration of his weakness as university leader.

children.name: subtle c2
children.definition: subtle/ˈsʌtl/  a subtle change or difference is difficult to notice unless you look closely or think about it carefully: khó thấy, tinh vi
examples: ▪ the patterns look very similar, but there are subtle differences between them.
▪ we noticed some deterioration in her speech, but it was very subtle.
▪ it was around this time that i started to notice subtle changes in clive’s character.

children.name: unobtrusive x
children.definition: unobtrusive/ˌʌnəbˈtruːsɪv◂/  something, especially an object, that is unobtrusive is not very noticeable, especially because it is small or ordinary compared to other things:kín đáo, không phô trương
examples: ▪ the aerial is small and unobtrusive, fitting closely to the chimney stack.
▪ the researchers will make their observations in the most unobtrusive way possible.
▪ hart, who attended law school with danforth, remembers him as ‘quiet and unobtrusive.’
unobtrusively[adverb]kín đáo, không phô trương
▪ the new hearing aid fits unobtrusively into the outer ear.

children.name: inconspicuous x
children.definition: inconspicuous/ˌɪnkənˈspɪkjuəs◂/  things or people that are inconspicuous are not noticeable because they look the same as the people or things around them:không lồ lộ, không dễ thấy
examples: ▪ carpet cleaner should always be tested in an inconspicuous spot first.
▪ the two bank robbers got in line at a nearby fast-food restaurant, hoping to be inconspicuous as police flooded the area.
inconspicuously[adverb]kín đáo
▪ throughout the meal she was inconspicuously passing food to the dog under the table.
▪ arriving late, we tried to take our seats as inconspicuously as possible.

children.name: obvious b1
children.definition: obvious a fact that is obvious is easy to see or realize: rõ ràng
examples: ▪ she tried to look grateful, but her disappointment was obvious.
it is obvious (to sb) that
▪ it’s obvious that paul is in love with liz.
▪ it was obvious to everyone that gina was lying.
obviously[adv]
▪ the doctor said he wants ann to come back for further tests and she’s obviously very worried.

children.name: of course b1
children.definition: of courseused to show that other people probably already know what you are saying is true, or expect to hear it : chắc chắn
examples: the second world war ended, of course, in 1945.
well, she won, of course.
you should of course keep copies of all your correspondence.
of course there will be some difficult times ahead.

children.name: bold b1
children.definition: boldadjectivenoticeable ( dam / ro net )
examples: strong in colour or shape ( hinh thuc ), and very noticeable( de nhan ) to the eye
_they painted the kitchen in boldcolours- crimson, purple and blue.

children.name: evident b2
children.definition: evidentadjectiveslightly formal ( hien nhien/ ranh ranh )
examples: easily seen or understood; obvious
_the full extent of the damage only became evident the following morning.
_fromthe smellitwas evidentthatthe drains had been blocked for several days.
( tu viec ngui, ro rang la nhung ong dan nuoc da bi vo nhieu ngay roi )
_harry's courage during his illness was evidenttoeveryone.
( su can dam cua harry trong suot con om da qua ro rang voi moi nguoi )
_her love for him was evidentinall that she did.
( tinh yeu cua co ay dang cho anh ta da ro rang trong nhung viec co ay da lam )
evidently b2slightly formal một cách rõ ràng
in a way that is easy tosee
_he was evidently upset by the news of the accident.
( rorang anh ay da lo lang boi nhung tin ve vu tai nan )
_a thin although evidently pregnant woman

children.name: naked c1
children.definition: nakedadjectivenot hidden hiển nhiên, rõ ràng
examples: [ before noun ]a naked feeling or quality is not hidden, although it is bad
_naked aggression/greed

children.name: visible
children.definition: adjectiverõ ràng, rõ rệt
examples: able or likely to attract public attention and be noticed
_in a very short period of time, she has become ahighlyvisible national leader.

children.name: under your nose c2
children.definition: (from) underyournose
examples: (us also(out from) underyournose)
used about something bad which happens in an obvious way but in a waythat you do notnotice or cannot prevent
_she stole the shoes from right under the assistant's nose.
